Nathan Deal office in 2011, the state’s rainy day fund has
   grown by 643 percent.

In his 2013 State of the State address, the governor bragged that the
   rainy day fund had grown 226 percent since he took office in 2011.

State rainy day funds collectively fell from $25.9 billion in FY 2007 to
   $10.4 billion in FY 2010, although they had bounced back to about $21.6
   billion by last fall, according to the National Conference of State
   Legislatures.

true false
   By Tom Kertscher • March 1, 2021

   Georgia’s rainy day fund had $116,021,961 before Deal took office in 2011
   and reached $377,971,440 by June 30, 2012, earning the governor a True
   rating from PolitiFact for his statement in the State of the State  in
   January 2013.
